data.text: قُلْ أَعُوذُ بِرَبِّ النَّاسِ مَلِكِ النَّاسِ إِلَـٰهِ النَّاسِ مِنْ شَرِّ الْوَسْوَاسِ الْخَنَّاسِ الَّذِي يُوَسْوِسُ فِي صُدُورِ النَّاسِ مِنَ الْجِنَّةِ وَالنَّاسِ

explanations.explanation: In the word 'النَّاسِ', at the 3rd letter (position 3 of 20), we find Noon Sakin. The next letter 'ن' (within the same word) belongs to the Yarmaloon letters (ي ر م ل و ن). This means we apply Idgham (إدغام), which is the rule of merging. Since the letter 'ن' is one of ي و م ن, you must merge the Noon/Tanween completely into this letter WITH a nasal sound (ghunnah). This nasal sound should be held for two counts.
explanations.urdu_explanation: لفظ 'النَّاسِ' میں، تیسرا حرف ، نون ساکن ہے۔ اگلا حرف 'ن' (اسی لفظ میں) یرملون (ي ر م ل و ن) میں سے ہے۔ یہاں ادغام ہوگا۔ چونکہ 'ن' (ی و م ن) میں سے ہے، اس لیے نون/تنوین کو غنہ کے ساتھ اس حرف میں ملا دیں۔

explanations.explanation: In the word 'مِنْ', at the last letter (position 2 of 2), we find Noon Sakin. The next letter 'ش' (from the word 'شَرِّ') is not from the throat letters, not from Yarmaloon, not Ba, and not Alif. Therefore, we apply Ikhfa (إخفاء), which means you must hide or conceal the Noon/Tanween with a nasal sound (ghunnah). The sound is between clear pronunciation and complete merging - not fully pronounced, not fully merged.
